flags.evidence:
Key inputs are loaded exclusively from pre-existing local files under ../data (modal_age.dta, cbsa_county_crosswalk.csv, election_2016/2020/2024.csv) with no code in the repository to (i) download these from the sources described in the manuscript (Acemoglu et al. technology data; Tony McGovern GitHub election compilations; NBER/Census crosswalk), (ii) document exact upstream URLs/commit hashes, or (iii) verify file integrity (checksums). This limits reproducibility/auditability and makes it hard to confirm the data correspond to the stated sources and versions.: tech_raw <- read_dta("../data/modal_age.dta")
...
crosswalk <- read_csv("../data/cbsa_county_crosswalk.csv",
                      show_col_types = FALSE)
...
elec_2016 <- read_csv("../data/election_2016.csv",
                      show_col_types = FALSE)
...
elec_2020 <- read_csv("../data/election_2020.csv",
                      show_col_types = FALSE)
...
elec_2024 <- read_csv("../data/election_2024.csv",
                      show_col_types = FALSE)

Comment says technology terciles are computed "(within year)", but the code computes ntile() on the full pooled dataset (no group_by(year) prior to ntile). This can change tercile cutoffs and interpretation (pooled terciles vs year-specific terciles). The manuscript’s tercile discussion appears consistent with pooled terciles, so this is likely a documentation/intent mismatch rather than p-hacking, but it should be clarified and aligned (either group_by(year) before ntile, or update comment/text).: # Technology terciles (within year)
tech_tercile = ntile(modal_age_mean, 3),

summary.executive_summary: Minor code quality issues detected, but no evidence of data fabrication or manipulation.
